content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. Particle <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi></math> moves along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></math>-axis such that, for time <math alttext="t greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, its position is given by <math alttext="x sub P, of t, equals, 6 minus 4 times e to the negative t power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>P</mi></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></math>. Particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> moves along the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></math>-axis such that, for time <math alttext="t greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, its velocity is given by <math alttext="v sub Q, of t, equals, the fraction 1 over t squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>Q</mi></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the position of particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> is <math alttext="y sub Q, of 1, equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>Q</mi></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. (a) Find <math alttext="v sub P, of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>P</mi></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, the velocity of particle <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi></math> at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. Particle <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi></math> moves along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></math>-axis such that, for time <math alttext="t greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, its position is given by <math alttext="x sub P, of t, equals, 6 minus 4 times e to the negative t power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mi>P</mi></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></math>. Particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> moves along the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></math>-axis such that, for time <math alttext="t greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, its velocity is given by <math alttext="v sub Q, of t, equals, the fraction 1 over t squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>Q</mi></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the position of particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> is <math alttext="y sub Q, of 1, equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>Q</mi></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. (a) Find <math alttext="v sub P, of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi>P</mi></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, the velocity of particle <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi></math> at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>.

(b) Find <math alttext="a sub Q, of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>Q</mi></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, the acceleration of particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find all times <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="t greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, when the speed of particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> is decreasing. Justify your answer.

(c) Find <math alttext="y sub Q, of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>Q</mi></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, the position of particle <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) As <math alttext="t approaches infinity" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>∞</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, which particle will eventually be farther from the origin? Give a reason for your answer.

topic.text: 1.15: Connecting Limits at Infinity and Horizontal Asymptotes

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
